verses.text: Then Miriam and Aaron spoke against Moses because of the Cushite woman whom he had married—for he had married a Cushite woman.
verses.comment: Miriam and Aaron's criticism is linked to Moses' marriage, possibly revealing deeper jealousy over his special status. Some traditions identify the Cushite woman as Zipporah.

verses.text: They said, 'Has the LORD only spoken through Moses? Has He not also spoken through us?' And the LORD heard it.
verses.comment: Their protest goes beyond marriage, challenging God's chosen leader. This foreshadows later authority disputes (see Num. 16:3).

verses.text: Now Moses was very humble, more than any other man on the face of the earth.
verses.comment: Moses' humility is highlighted here, a trait later seen perfected in Christ (Matt. 11:29).

verses.text: Immediately the LORD said to Moses and to Aaron and to Miriam, 'Come out, you three, to the Tent of Meeting.' So the three of them came out.
verses.comment: God’s command to all three emphasizes His personal role as judge and the seriousness of challenging divinely established leadership.

verses.text: Then the LORD came down in a pillar of cloud and stood at the entrance of the tent and called Aaron and Miriam. And they both came forward.
verses.comment: The cloud is a visible sign of the divine presence, a prefiguration of the ways God would later dwell among His people.

verses.text: He said, 'Hear My words: If there is a prophet among you, I, the LORD, make Myself known to him in a vision; I speak to him in a dream.'
verses.comment: God reveals that prophetic communication is typically indirect (visions, dreams), not face-to-face, showing the unique grace given to Moses.

verses.text: 'Not so with My servant Moses; he is faithful in all My house.'
verses.comment: Moses' faithfulness is honored as unparalleled, serving as a type for Christ’s perfect faithfulness (Heb. 3:6).

verses.text: 'With him I speak mouth to mouth, clearly and not in riddles, and he beholds the form of the LORD. Why then were you not afraid to speak against My servant, against Moses?'
verses.comment: Moses' extraordinary intimacy with God points forward to the full revelation given in Christ, the true mediator (1 Tim. 2:5).

verses.text: The anger of the LORD burned against them, and He departed.
verses.comment: The Lord's withdrawal indicates a temporary removal of His favor and presence, a warning seen throughout the Scriptures.

verses.text: When the cloud lifted from over the tent, behold, Miriam was leprous, white as snow. Aaron turned toward Miriam, and behold, she was leprous.
verses.comment: Miriam’s leprosy is a visible sign of divine judgment for her rebellion, highlighting the seriousness of opposing God's order.

verses.text: Then Aaron said to Moses, 'Oh, my lord, please do not hold this sin against us, in which we have acted foolishly and have sinned.'
verses.comment: Aaron’s plea for forgiveness reflects both confession and respect for Moses’ spiritual authority as intercessor.

verses.text: 'Let her not be as one dead, whose flesh is half consumed when he comes out of his mother's womb!'
verses.comment: Aaron’s description uses powerful imagery, underscoring both the severity of leprosy and the compassion needed in leadership.

verses.text: So Moses cried out to the LORD, 'Heal her now, O God, I beg You!'
verses.comment: Moses intercedes selflessly, prefiguring the perfect intercession of Christ (Rom. 8:34).

verses.text: But the LORD said to Moses, 'If her father had but spit in her face, would she not be shamed for seven days? Let her be shut outside the camp for seven days, and after that, she may be brought in again.'
verses.comment: God’s discipline is both just and restorative, showing His mercy after appropriate repentance and correction. The seven-day period points to purification practices.

verses.text: So Miriam was shut outside the camp seven days, and the people did not set out until Miriam was brought in again.
verses.comment: The entire community waits for Miriam’s restoration, reflecting the unity of God’s people and showing the importance of reconciliation after discipline.

verses.text: Afterward the people moved from Hazeroth and camped in the Wilderness of Paran.
verses.comment: The journey resumes only after full restoration, a reminder of how God desires His people to move forward together in unity and order, restored and purified.
